newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore, Hong Kong to sign new investment pact.
newsitem.headline: Singapore, Hong Kong to sign new investment pact.

text.p: Singapore and Hong Kong are negotiating a bilateral investment pact to boost trade ties as Hong Kong prepares its transition to a Special Administrative Region (SAR) of China, the Business Times said on Monday.
The two sides have been negotiating an Investment Protection and Promotion Agreement (IPPA).
"The IPPA seeks to give the investment community added confidence in each other's territory," said Chan Heng Wing, Singapore's consul-general to Hong Kong.

"Singapore is expanding its enormous ties with Hong Kong because we believe that Hong Kong will maintain its prosperity and way of life as before. We are confident that Hong Kong will revert smoothly from Britain to China," Chan said.
The IPPA has been under negotiation for the past year, the newspaper said.
It said that like the many monetary cooperation agreements that the Hong Kong Monetary Authority signed with its regional counterparts, the IPPA is part of confidence-building measures.
Hong Kong's handover to China at midnight on June 30 has caused some jitters in the foreign business community.
The Business Times said that with or without the agreement, investment between the two countries have been growing.
Singapore's private sector investments in Hong Kong totalled Singapore $6.3 billion at the end of 1995, official statistics show. Most of the invesments have been in property.
